What: The site checks whether it's being loaded inside another webpage (like an iframe) or if it's the main page you're visiting.
Why: This helps them understand the context of how their page is being accessed.

What: The site reads small text files stored on your device to identify you when you return.
Why: These cookies help remember your preferences and track your visits.

What: The site creates unique codes for your browsing session.
Why: These codes help them track your activities during your visit and distinguish you from other visitors.

What: The site measures how long different parts of the webpage take to load, including network connection times, server response times, and how quickly content appears on your screen.
Why: This information helps them optimize their site's performance.

What: The site checks how you arrived at their page - whether you typed the address directly, clicked a link, used the back button, or refreshed the page.
Why: This helps them understand user behavior and traffic sources.

What: The site monitors when you leave the page or close the browser tab to understand your browsing patterns and how long you stay on their site.
Why: This data helps them improve user engagement.

What: The site tracks any errors that occur while you're browsing to improve their service and identify potential issues.
Why: This helps them maintain a smooth user experience.

What: The site tracks whether their webpage is currently visible on your screen or hidden behind other windows/tabs.
Why: This information helps them understand user engagement and optimize content delivery.
